problem_text: b) An abstract group-theoretical property Σ is called radical (in our sense) if, in any group G, the join Σ(G) of all normal Σ-subgroups is a Σ-subgroup. Is the property N^0 (see Archive, 1.38) radical? Sh. S. Kemkhadze
answer:
No.
The group SLn(Z) for sufficiently large n ⩾ 3 contains a non-abelian finite simple group and therefore is not an N^0-group.
On the other hand, as shown in (M. I. Kargapolov, Yu. I. Merzlyakov, in: Itogi Nauki. Algebra. Topologiya. Geometriya, 1966, VINITI, Moscow, 1968, 57–90 (Russian)), it is the product of its congruence-subgroups mod 2 and mod 3, which have central systems and hence are N^0-groups (see Archive, 1.38). (Yu. I. Merzlyakov, 1973.)
